Hey there â€” thanks for visiting **andrewbumpas.com**.  
Your privacy matters, and I want to be upfront about what kind of information this site collects, how itâ€™s used, and how itâ€™s kept safe.

---

## 1. What This Site Collects

**1.1 Information You Share**
If you choose to get in touch (like through a contact form or email), you might share things such as:

- Your name
- Your email address
- Whatever message you send along

Thatâ€™s it â€” no hidden data collection or sign-ups here.

**1.2 Automatic Info**
Like most websites, some basic technical info is automatically collected to keep things running smoothly, such as:

- Which pages you visit
- Your browser and device type
- Rough location (city or region)
- How you found the site (like through Google or social media)

This data is anonymous and helps me understand how people use the site so I can make it better.

## 2. How the Information Is Used

Any information collected is used only to:

- Respond if you reach out
- Improve site content or performance
- Keep an eye on general traffic trends

Your info will **never be sold, traded, or shared** with anyone else for marketing or advertising purposes.

## 3. Cookies & Analytics

This site may use tools like **Google Analytics** or similar services to see how people use the site â€” things like page views and visit duration.  
These tools use cookies (small text files stored in your browser) to collect that info.

You can clear or disable cookies anytime in your browser settings â€” the site will still work just fine.

## 4. Third-Party Services

andrewbumpas.com may rely on a few trusted services to function, like:

- A web hosting provider (for storing and serving the site)
- Google Analytics (for anonymous traffic stats)

These third parties have their own privacy policies, and they only collect whatâ€™s needed to provide their services.

## 5. Data Security

Reasonable steps are taken to keep your information safe, but please remember that no website or online service can guarantee absolute security.

## 6. Childrenâ€™s Privacy

This site isnâ€™t aimed at children under 13, and no personal information is knowingly collected from them.

## 7. Updates to This Policy

This Privacy Policy may be updated occasionally as the site evolves. Any changes will be reflected here with a new â€œlast updatedâ€ date.

## 8. Contact

If you have any questions about how your information is handled, just reach out:

Does anyone else still drive or walk or bike around to different neighborhoods to awe and ooo at people's light displays? I remember fondly piling into the car as a kid, the chill of winter air mixing with the excitement of seeing colorful lights twinkling on houses. All the different arrangements, colors and sometimes even music. 

Lights on a house at night have a kind of common magic. But still you have a subset of lights. Maybe a handful of different bulbs, string types, colors etc. Yet some displays hit you like a small, brilliant surprise. That feeling is what I mean by originality: for the majority only a handful of similiar items, but a human arrangement and creativity that makes each display unique.

AI isnâ€™t just a creative assistant; it can also be a sameness machine.

Think about the rise of app-driven LED strings â€” the same preset palettes, the same gobos and chase patterns distributed by default in companion apps. Brands like Govee make it easy to load a handful of popular patterns and share them. Thatâ€™s great for convenience, but when thousands of people choose the same presets, the neighborhood loses the small variations that used to make displays feel local.

When creativity is reduced to â€œpick a preset,â€ originality suffers. An algorithm trained on the most liked or most shared patterns will recommend whatâ€™s already popular. Optimization amplifies conformity. The result: houses that technically glow beautifully but emotionally read as uniform.

This effect shows up in other places too â€” social feeds, stock photo libraries, even AI-generated art marketplaces. If the reward signal favors familiarity, creators (and buyers) are nudged toward safe choices. With decorative lighting, the stakes are small but visible: a walk down any block at night starts to feel like a showroom rather than a neighborhood.

That doesnâ€™t make AI or smart lights the enemy. Theyâ€™re tools that can either flatten or free up creativity depending on how you use them. Hereâ€™s a short approach to avoid the trap:

- Resist the first preset. Choose a raw color or two and tweak spacing, timing, or placement manually.
- Add a constraint tied to your home â€” a roofline quirk, a sentimental ornament, or a favored color that has meaning for you.
- Share oddness, not just polish. If you like a weird combination, itâ€™s worth keeping; those choices are what shift the visible taste.

If we want our streets to feel alive, someone has to opt out of the default. That small refusal â€” leaving a preset off, running a slightly awkward string of vintage bulbs, or twining lights around a crooked post â€” is how originality survives in an era of perfectly optimized patterns.
